sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acute coronary syndrome, Non-ST-Elevation: 25 mcg/kg IV within 5 minutes then 0.15 mcg/kg/min IV for up to 18 hours
  • Acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction - Percutaneous coronary intervention: Initial bolus, 25 mcg/kg IV; maintenance infusion, 0.15 mcg/kg/min IV plus unfractionated heparin (guideline dosing)
  • Acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction - Percutaneous coronary intervention: Initial bolus, 10 mcg/kg administered intracoronary or IV over 1 minute; maintenance infusion, 0.15 mcg/kg/min IV for 24 to 36 hours (study dosing)

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• Renal impairment, CrCl less than 60 mL/min: 25 mcg/kg IV within 5 minutes, then 0.075 mcg/kg/min IV up to 18 hours
  • Renal impairment, CrCl less than 30 mL/min: Reduce infusion by 50%
  • Geriatric: No dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Acute coronary syndrome, Non-ST-Elevation
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Acute ST segment elevation myocardial infarction - Percutaneous coronary intervention
  • Cerebrovascular accident

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• bleeding, active internal, or a history of bleeding diathesis, major surgery, or severe physical trauma within previous 30 days
  • hypersensitivity, severe (ie, anaphylaxis), to tirofiban
  • thrombocytopenia following prior tirofiban administration

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• bleeding events, including fatalities, have been reported; typically at arterial access site; increased risk with concomitant use of fibrinolytics, oral anticoagulants, or antiplatelet drugs; minimize traumatic procedures (ie, punctures, intramuscular injections, nasotracheal intubation)
  • thrombocytopenia, profound, has been reported; previous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor antagonist exposure may increase risk; monitoring recommended; discontinue use if thrombocytopenia occurs
  • report suspected adverse events to the US Food and Drug Administration 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Tirofiban: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Cardiovascular:Bradyarrhythmia (4%)
  • Hematologic:Bleeding, Minor (10.5%)
  • Reproductive:Pain in pelvis (6%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Dissecting aneurysm of coronary artery (5%)
  • Hematologic:Bleeding, Major (1.4%), Thrombocytopenia (up to 1.5%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Neurologic:Intracranial hemorrhage
  • Respiratory:Pulmonary hemorrhage

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Tirofiban hydrochloride, a non-peptide platelet glycoprotein (GP) antagonist, inhibits aggregation of platelets by reversibly antagonizing fibrinogen binding to the GP IIb/IIIa receptor.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IV administration only
  • Intravenous
    • do not add other drugs or remove solution directly from bag with syringe
    • do not use plastic containers in series connections.
    • discard any unused solution

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduced incidence of thrombotic cardiovascular events, including myocardial infarction, refractory ischemia, or repeat cardiac procedures, is indicative of efficacy
  • platelet count, 6 hours after treatment initiation, and at least daily during therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of bleeding or bruising.
  • Side effects may include pelvic pain, leg pain, dizziness, edema/swelling, and sweating.
  • Advise patient that there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
